refs.text: Syrian army deserters kill 10 troops, Assad to meet Arab League committee Wednesday

20 October.event: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said 19 people were killed in Syria, including seven civilians shot by security forces in the Homs Governorate as well as nine loyalist soldiers killed in a rocket attack attributed to defectors. An Arab League delegation led by Secretary-General Nabil al-Arabi arrived in Damascus for talks.

refs.text: Arab league mounts mediation as 19 killed in Syria; U.N. urged to refer Assad’s crimes to ICC
Army Defectors in Syria Take Credit for Attack

20 October.event: There were protests in Damascus in support of the Syrian National Council whilst some analysts began describing the situation as the beginning of a "sectarian war".

refs.text: Libya, Syria and Middle East unrest – Thursday 27 October 2011
Robert Fisk: Syria slips towards sectarian war

20 October.event: 36 people were reported killed in Syria, most of them in Hama, whilst thousands of protesters marched demanding a no-fly zone be implemented, such as the one in Libya. Over 100 people were wounded and 500 arrested. Despite the threat of violence, around 170 protests took place on Friday, the traditional day of protest.

refs.text: 36 killed in Syria as activists call for 'no-fly' zone

20 October.event: State media claimed that armed gangs assaulted the main police station in Homs, which activists attributed to defectors from the army.

refs.text: 36 killed in Syria as activists call for 'no-fly' zone

20 October.event: A Lebanese official claimed that Syrian soldiers were laying landmines along the border between Syria and Lebanon near illegal border crossings.

refs.text: Syrian army 'laying mines on Lebanese border'

20 October.event: A former consultant to Bashar Al Assad claimed that if the crackdown on protestors continued, that Syria would soon slide into a civil war.

refs.text: Ex-Assad consultant warns of a civil war
Syria protesters reportedly demand 'no fly' zone

20 October.event: There were reports of 17 pro Assad soldiers being killed in clashes with the Free Syrian Army in Homs.

refs.text: 20 Syrian soldiers killed in 'clashes with deserters'
SYRIA: DESERTERS KILL 17 SOLDIERS IN HOMS

20 October.event: Tanks and artillery blasted the Homs neighbourhood of Bab Amr, the site of a 90-man defection from the Syrian security forces two days before, causing several casualties.

refs.text: Syrian Forces Strike Homs for Second Day

20 October.event: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claimed that 20 soldiers died and 53 were injured in clashes between loyalist troops and "presumed deserters" in Bab Amr as well.

refs.text: 20 Syrian soldiers die in ‘clashes with deserters’

20 September.event: The White House says U.S. President Barack Obama and Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan have agreed to "increase pressure" on the Syrian regime to end the violence against antigovernment protesters. The U.S. and Turkish leaders discussed Syria in a meeting on 20 September on the sidelines of the annual UN General Assembly in New York. UN officials have estimated that pro-Assad forces have killed some 2,700 people since the uprising against the regime started in March, including at least 100 children.

refs.text: Obama, Erdogan Agree To 'Increase Pressure' On Syrian Regime

20 September.event:
Speaking separately in New York, the foreign minister of Syria's neighbor Iraq said a change of regime in Syria appears inevitable.
Tanks surrounded the town of al-Kiswa, opposition activists claimed.

refs.text: Tue, 20 Sep 2011, 12:36 GMT+3 – Syria

20 September.event: Prime Minister Erdogan of Turkey announced that Turkey has cut of all relations and contacts with Syria, and is considering joining in on the sanctions.

refs.text: Erdogan cuts all contacts with Syrian administration and considers sanctions

20 September.event: The Syrian opposition announced its intention for another Friday of protests, this time under the banner Friday of Unification against the Regime.

refs.text: U.S. ambassador in Syria says crackdown risks sectarian strife prior to Friday of ‘unity’

20 September.event: Protesters took to the street, with protests occurring in Hama, Homs, Damascus, Aleppo, and Daraa. 50,000 attended an anti-government march in Homs. 12 protesters across Syria were killed by security forces. Amnesty international announced the death and mutilation of an 18-year-old girl in the hands of the Syrian army. The girl's body was returned to her mother by the Syrian army, and the corpse had clear signs of torture, including skin ripped off and her arms cut off.

refs.text: More deaths in Syria as sanctions tighten

20 September.event: Turkey continued to attempt to alienate the Syrian government, and has announced that it will be enforcing an arms embargo on Syria, and confiscate any weapon deliveries to Syria by ship. The European Union also toughened sanctions against the Syrian government, while Switzerland established a ban on Syrian oil imports on Friday.

refs.text: Turkey seizes Syrian ship with weapons – PM Erdogan

20 September.event: Syria pressed on with a crackdown on anti-regiment dissent Sunday, dispatching troop reinforcements to the flashpoint province of Homs and security forces near Damascus, activists said. "Military reinforcements were sent to Rastan, deploying around the building housing military security, and others to Qusseir," a town on the border with Lebanon, they said. The Syrian army had strengthened its presence in Qusseir on Saturday and previous days after many civilians tried to flee the area to escape the violence. The deployments come a day after activists reported that security forces had killed 12 civilians in Qusseir, in the central province of Homs, and one more in Hama, further north. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights which carried the toll said that the 12 civilians were killed in Qusseir during raids for people wanted by the authorities.

refs.text: http://web.archive.org/web/20130610014822/http://www.france24.com/en/20110925-syria-sends-troop-reinforcements-homs-area

20 September.event: Syrian security forces killed at least 76 people in the past five days as part of a crackdown on protests against President Bashar al-Assad’s government, a human rights activist said. At least seven people were killed today in the central governorate of Homs, following the death of 15 protesters yesterday there and in Hama, the northern province of Idlib and in the southern area of Daraa, where the uprising against Assad began in March, Mahmoud Merhi, head of the Arab Organization for Human Rights, said by phone today. State media said “terrorists” killed General Nael al-Dakhil, deputy chief of the chemistry faculty at Al-Baath University in Homs, and Mohammad Ali Akeel, deputy dean of its architecture faculty. Activists said security forces murdered them after they expressed opposition to the crackdown. Homs is a focal point of the uprising against Assad’s government and the hometown of his wife, Asma.

refs.text: Syria Forces Kill 76 in Five Days of Violence, Activist Says

20 September.event: The Free Syrian Army claimed to have destroyed 17 loyalist tanks in the town of Rastan, and there were reports of more defections occurring with the ranks of the Syrian Army, raising fears that civil war could break out.

refs.text: As troops defect, Syria risks civil war

20 September.event: At least 38 loyalist soldiers were injured in Rastan, some critically.
The Harmoush battalion also reported that it killed 80 loyalist soldiers in fighting.

refs.text: Defected brigade says it has killed 80 members of Assad’s forces

20 September.event: About 100 "pro-assad" protesters attempted to attack the U.S. ambassadors convoy, but Ambassador Ford and his convoy remained unharmed in the incident. Security forces killed 17 protesters throughout Syria, and the Opposition prepared for a new Friday of Protests, under the Banner of Friday of Victory for the Levant and Yemen.

refs.text: https://web.archive.org/20110929172319/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/09/29/bloomberg_articlesLSAL2H6JTSE8.DTL

20 September.event: Syrian security forces have clashed with protesters, killing at least 30 people as tens of thousands have rallied across the country calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down, activists say. There were reports that the security forces opened fire on protesters at several of the demonstrations on Friday, and that there were also clashes between troops who have joined the protesters and those loyal to Assad. Protests were reported in suburbs of Damascus, the capital, as well as in the southern province of Deraa, the northwestern province of Idlib, in Hama, Homs and several other cities.
An opposition activist, speaking to Al Jazeera on condition of anonymity, described the scene at one protest in Damascus:

refs.text: 'Dozens killed' in Syria protests

20 September.event: The area where I stay now, a protest went around and it was soon attacked by security forces, and the attack included batons, hitting with batons, some gas bombs and later live ammunition that was shot all around. At least one person was injured. Later, after that, we could see a number of soldiers – we could see a clash between the soldiers and the security forces. And my friends confirmed that eight soldiers at least defected and shot back on the security forces.

21 December.event: Syrian security forces were accused of massacring the entire village of Kfar Owaid, about 30 miles from the Turkish border, with rockets, machine guns, tanks, and nail bombs. The Syrian army surrounded the unarmed villagers in the Budnaya Valley after forcing them to flee their homes, activist groups and a witness said. The troops allegedly killed the more than 100 people trapped inside in an attack that lasted for hours, in one of the deadliest single events of the uprising to date.

refs.text: Syrian troops 'wipe out village'
Activists say at least 100 killed in Syrian town

21 December.event: Under a new law, the Syrian government said it would execute anyone smuggling weapons for the sake of committing "terrorist acts". According to Al Jazeera, became clear that "army defectors have taken control over some towns and villages, almost as though they have created some sort of safe area, where protesters from other regions were seeking a safe haven and where defectors were able to operate from".

refs.text: SNC calls for action to halt Idlib 'massacre'

21 December.event: The Syrian official media reported that the army arrested tens of armed men and seized weapons in operations across the country.

refs.text: In Syria, Surge in Killings Reported Before Observer Mission

21 December.event: SANA reported that Assad supporters gathered in Damascus' Umayyad Square to honor the army and to watch the unveiling of a 7-meter statue of a Syrian soldier.

refs.text: Masses Gather at Umayyad Square in Appreciation of Army's Sacrifices

21 December.event: Fresh raids and gunfire by government forces on Thursday killed at least 19 people, most of them in the central city of Homs and northern Idlib province, according to the London-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Local Coordination Committees.

refs.text: Despite observers, Syria's Assad hikes crackdown

21 December.event: The Syrian government updated the casualty figures of its soldiers to 2,000, as the Arab League prepared an agreed observer mission into the country, amongst rising civilian, defector, and soldier deaths from ongoing clashes in the Zawiya mountains near Idlib.

refs.text: Arab League delegates head to Syria over 'bloodbath'

21 December.event: Two car bombings in Damascus at security offices killed civilians and some soldiers, leaving 44 dead and 163 wounded. Syrian officials said that Al Qaeda was suspected of carrying out the attack. A website, which supposedly belonged to the Muslim Brotherhood, emerged claiming the attacks. It was later revealed that the website was fake and made by the Syrian regime only one day before the bombings. Also, many members of the organization were interviewed on several channels and denied any relation between them and the Damascus events.

refs.text: Muslim Brotherhood denies Syria bombing claim

21 December.event: Meanwhile, the opposition said the Syrian government may have orchestrated the attacks to reinforce its narrative of a country beset by terrorist-related violence.

refs.text: Funeral for Damascus Bombing Victims Turns into Pro-Assad Rally

21 December.event: The government of Lebanon had reportedly warned Damascus two days prior that Al Qaida infiltrated Syria from Arsal, Lebanon.

refs.text: Lebanon warned Syria warned of al Qaeda infiltration

21 December.event: Daily Friday protests occurred throughout Syria, most notably in Idlib, Homs, Qamishli, Hama, Damascus and its suburbs. As many as 28 people were killed as Syrian security forces continued with its crackdown against protesters and dissents in the country, Al Arabiya reported, citing Syrian activists.

refs.text: Arab League monitors to leave for Syria Monday as more deaths reported in crackdown

21 December.event: Thousands rallied in support of Assad in Damascus at the funeral of the victims of the previous day's bombings, blaming the attacks on the Syrian opposition and Qatar. Arab League Secretary-General Nabil Elaraby condemned the attacks in a statement.

refs.text: Funeral for Damascus Bombing Victims Turns into Pro-Assad Rally

21 December.event: Meanwhile, Oil Minister Sufian Allaw said oil production in Syria had fallen by between 30 percent and 35 percent due to foreign sanctions preventing exports.

refs.text: Allaw: current output was about 260,000 barrels per day

21 December.event: Sudanese General Mohammed Ahmed Mustafa al-Dabi, the leader of a planned Arab League observer mission, arrived in Damascus to meet with the Syrian government ahead of the mission's official start.

refs.text: First Arab monitors arrive in Syria: source

21 December.event: Burhan Ghalioun called for the Arab League and the United Nations Security Council to coordinate efforts to hold the Syrian government accountable for the bloodshed. In the Homsi neighborhood of Baba Amr, at least 15 civilians were killed by artillery bombardment, activists said. As many as 4,000 soldiers were reported to have surrounded the city.

refs.text: Syrian National Council calls for Arab League monitor to go to besieged Homs

21 December.event: Residents said at least 34 were killed in Homs, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said four died in Hama, two died in Idlib, one died in Daraa, and one more died in a suburb of Damascus as a result of security forces' actions, for a total death toll of 42 throughout the country related to the uprising for the day.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

21 December.event: Some Homs residents posted amateur video to the Internet showing what appear to be army tanks moving through the city, firing on apartment buildings with machine guns and mortar rounds, and mangled bodies and pools of blood, as well as ruined cars and power lines, in the streets of the city. At least one resident reported seeing army ambulances carrying wounded soldiers, suggesting that militant elements of the Syrian opposition were fighting back against the military crackdown in Homs. The Observatory also reported clashes and arrests in Aleppo.

refs.text: Syria Violence: Government Tanks Unleash Fire On Protesters, Killing At Least 20

21 December.event: Meanwhile, 50 Arab League monitors headed to Damascus as opposition members sought to downplay the mission, saying Syrian authorities were likely to stymie its chances of uncovering the truth and block observers' access to some of the worst-hit parts of the country, and the French government insisted on greater transparency.

refs.text: Arab monitors head to Syria, opposition skeptical

21 December.event: The observers arrived in the Syrian capital after sundown, sources told Reuters.

refs.text: First Arab monitors arrive in Syria: source

21 December.event: At least 11 tanks that had been shelling the neighbourhood of Baba Amr in Homs, according to residents and opposition activists, reportedly withdrew ahead of Arab League monitors' visit to the city.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

21 December.event: protesters reportedly converged on Clock Square in the center of the city, apparently after hearing Arab League monitors were in the area, but an activist said security forces began firing tear gas and live ammunition and prevented them from occupying the square. Elsewhere in Homs, including in besieged Baba Amr, the Observatory said gunfire, including volleys from snipers, impaired the free movement of residents.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

21 December.event: Although General Dabi, the leader of the observer team, said the day proceeded well and "all sides were very responsive", amateur video footage posted on the Internet appeared to show anti-government Homsis unsuccessfully pleading with monitors to travel further into the Baba Amr neighbourhood, where extensive violence had been reported.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

21 December.event: Avaaz claimed similar scenes of civil protest and regime violence in Hama, where thousands of demonstrators marching to al-Assi Square in the city centre were scattered by troops firing live ammunition, according to activists. Thirty-three deaths were reported in total throughout Syria by the LCC, including 13 in Homs, four in Daraa, four near Damascus, three at Damascus University, three in Hama, three in Idlib, two in Deir ez-Zor, and one in Latakia. The incident at Damascus University occurred when, the Observatory claimed, a student recently detained and tortured by the regime opened fire on fellow students who vocally supported Assad. The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on the school shooting, but made no mention of any political motivation on the shooter's part. SANA also claimed a terrorist attack shut down a natural gas pumping operation in Homs Governorate.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

21 December.event: At least 13 people were killed in fresh violence across Syria, activists said, as Arab League observers continued their mission. Six of the dead were reportedly killed while protesting in Hama. Local rights groups say others were killed in Homs, Aleppo, and Idlib. Video shared by activists from the protest in Hama showed gunshots being fired and black smoke rising above the city. Dozens of men were marching through the streets, chanting "Where are the Arab monitors?" In Deraa, army defectors killed at least four Syrian soldiers in an ambush.

refs.text: Fresh violence hits Syria flashpoint towns

21 December.event: Protesters demanded the removal of Mustafa Dabi as leader of the Arab League monitoring team as observers visited Hama, where six more people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Al Jazeera reported that an anonymous official with the observing mission in Syria had said monitors had witnessed shelling in Homs and it was apparent some parts of the city were controlled by the Free Syrian Army. The official, whose report directly contradicted Dabi's account of the situation, predicted the mission was doomed to fail. The LCC put the nationwide death toll at 35 for the day,

refs.text: Violence and doubts mar Syria monitor mission

21 December.event: while the Observatory said 26 were confirmed dead, with four deaths allegedly occurring in Douma after security forces fired live ammunition into a crowd of about 20,000 massing at its Grand Mosque for a protest ahead of an expected visit by Arab League observers. The Observatory said Douma residents responded to the shootings in their city by organising a mass strike and flooding into the city square for a sit-in thousands strong. The report could not be immediately confirmed, nor could rumours that Arab League vehicles were sighted in Douma. Hundreds also reportedly protested in Midan, a central Damascus neighbourhood, before being dispersed by soldiers shooting tear gas. The Observatory claimed 150,000 marched in the streets in Idlib Governorate, its largest demonstration in recent days. After meeting with Nabil Elaraby, head of the Arab League, Syrian National Council leader Burhan Ghalioun said he feared the Syrian government held more than 100,000 detainees and could execute them "to say there are no prisoners" if Arab League monitors demanded access to facilities in which they are imprisoned.

refs.text: Arab League monitors stoke anti-government protests in Syria

21 December.event: Activists said more than 130 protesters had been confirmed killed, including six children, since the Arab League observers arrived in Syria earlier in the week.

refs.text: Syrian Troops Filmed 'Targeting Civilians'

21 December.event: During the day, that reported death toll grew to 32 following attacks from security forces. BBC News gave a death toll of 35 for the day.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

21 December.event: In what seemed to be the largest day of demonstrating, with more than 500,000 people demonstrating in two governorates alone: Hama and Idlib, over 6 million people are said to have rallied in Syria against Bashar Al-Assad, according to activists. Tens of thousands protested in Damascus, as well as tens of thousands in Homs. Smaller demonstrations occurred in Daraa, Deir Ezzor, and Aleppo.

refs.text: Clashes erupt as protests spread across Syria

21 December.event: Amateur video posted online appeared to show an orange-vested Arab League observer in Daraa responding to residents' claims that snipers were nearby by saying he had seen the snipers himself and telling them the monitors planned to ask the Syrian government to remove any snipers from Daraa within 24 hours.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

21 December.event: In Cairo, the SNC and the National Coordination Body for Democratic Change in Syria signed onto a political roadmap for a transition to democracy in Syria to be put into effect if Assad is deposed.

refs.text: Syrian Opposition Groups Unite to Chart Path to Democracy

21 December.event: Activists reported at least nine deaths, at least three of them in Homs, at least one in Damascus, and at least one in Abu Kamal, as security forces attacked large protests across the country. The LCC said some protests evolved from funeral marches for demonstrators killed the day before.

refs.text: 9 Killed in Syria, Opposition Groups Unite

21 December.event: Al Jazeera reported that the number of statements received by the network from Arab League observers critical of the regime's crackdown had mounted over the past two days. Meanwhile, the SNC signed a deal with the National Co-ordination Committee, to work together on developing a "parliamentary system for a democratic, pluralistic civil state [that] guarantees the exchange of power through elections".

refs.text: Arab mission warns Syria as opposition unites

21 December.event: The head of the Arab League's observing team, General Mustafa Dabi, said in an interview with the BBC News on Newshour that no observers saw snipers in Deraa, contradicting amateur video showing an observer telling activists he saw snipers in the city centre. Dabi claimed that the observer was making "a hypothetical remark only".

refs.text: Arab League mission chief dispute Syria sniper account

21 November.event: At least four people were killed on Monday as Syrian security forces carried out raids in and around the flashpoint central city of Homs, rights and activist groups reported. "Two people were killed and 7 others were wounded in Homs while 2 others died and 8 were wounded in (nearby) Qusair by gunfire during raids on Monday morning by the army and security forces," said the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The military also raided the towns of Karnaz, Latalmleh and Kafar Nabude in the central province of Hama, the Britain-based Observatory said in a statement received in Nicosia.

refs.text: At least 4 killed in Syria's Homs: NGOs

21 November.event: Two people were injured after Syrian security forces attack a bus carrying Turkish citizens on a Hajj pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia.
Britain, France and Germany asked the United Nations to pass a resolution condemning Syrian violence against opposition protesters.

21 November.event: French foreign minister Alain Juppé assured Syrian opposition forces that NATO powers are considering to launch an intervention by imposing “humanitarian corridors or humanitarian zones” in the name of protecting civilians from the alleged abuses of the Assad regime.

21 November.event: The Syrian military claimed that the Free Syrian Army attacked a military base in the Homs province, killing 10 members of Assad's air force. Of the 10 killed, six were "elite military pilots" in the Homs Province Ambush

21 November.event: The Free Syrian Army ambushed the Syrian army in Idlib, killing eight loyalist soldiers. The Free Syrian Army had no casualties.

21 November.event: The Arab League agreed on economic sanctions against Syria, including a freeze on doing business with the Central Bank of Syria and the Syrian government, a travel ban on regime officials, and a suspension of infrastructure spending by Arab governments in Syria.

21 November.event: Three civilians were injured and one other killed in a raid by security forces in the town of Saraqeb. The Free Syrian Army also killed three loyalist soldiers and captured two others.

21 October \u2013 \"Friday of the Martyr.event: Deaths have been reported during the latest protests in Syria, including up to 16 in the flashpoint central city of Homs, according to activist groups. Two people were shot dead on Friday in Homs by security forces manning a checkpoint, while 14 more were killed by security forces as they participated in mass protests, many celebrating the death of former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, the opposition Local Co-ordination Committees said. Another civilian died when security forces opened fire on a funeral procession in the southern Deraa region, one of the focal points of opposition to Syrian President Bashar al Assad's government and two more people died in the central province of Hama, according to the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

refs.text: More deaths in Syria following fresh protests

21 October \u2013 \"Friday of the Martyr.event: Activists and residents said Syrian authorities have stepped up security in several cities and towns including the Damascus suburbs and Talbiseh near Homs. “(There is an) unprecedented presence of security today with snipers on rooftops and roadblocks inside the suburb,” an activist in Damascus suburb of Saqba said. Demonstrations also broke out in the ethnically Kurdish regions of Qamishli, Derbaseyeh, Malikiya and Amouda. In the town of Houla northwest of Homs, a crowd of several thousands held shoulders and waved old Syrian flags dating to before Assad’s Baath party took power in a coup 48 years ago. “Doctor (Assad), you are next!” read banners carried by the villagers, according to live video footage. Demonstrations also flared in Homs, the provincial capital 140 km (85 miles) north of Damascus, where three members of one family were also shot dead at an army roadblock in Bab Sbaa district on their way to prayers, local activists said.

21 October \u2013 \"Friday of the Martyr.event: Syria's military clampdown on protest hubs, and skirmishes pitting soldiers against gunmen, believed to be defectors, killed at least 11 people on Saturday, activists said. Meanwhile, Iran, Syria's key ally, took a tougher stance against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, openly condemning its crackdown on dissent that has left more than 3,000 people dead, most of them civilians, according to the United Nations. Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad condemned the "killings and massacre" in Syria in an interview with CNN, in the Islamic republic's strongest criticism of its neighbor's deadly repression of protests calling for greater freedom and the fall of the Assad regime.

Amnesty international announced the death and mutilation of an 18-year-old girl in the hands of the Syrian army. refs.text: More deaths in Syria as sanctions tighten

21 September.event: Turkey continued to attempt to alienate the Syrian government, and has announced that it will be enforcing an arms embargo on Syria, and confiscate any weapon deliveries to Syria by ship. The European Union also toughened sanctions against the Syrian government, while Switzerland established a ban on Syrian oil imports on Friday.

refs.text: Turkey seizes Syrian ship with weapons – PM Erdogan

21 September.event: Syria pressed on with a crackdown on anti-regiment dissent Sunday, dispatching troop reinforcements to the flashpoint province of Homs and security forces near Damascus, activists said. "Military reinforcements were sent to Rastan, deploying around the building housing military security, and others to Qusseir," a town on the border with Lebanon, they said. The Syrian army had strengthened its presence in Qusseir on Saturday and previous days after many civilians tried to flee the area to escape the violence. The deployments come a day after activists reported that security forces had killed 12 civilians in Qusseir, in the central province of Homs, and one more in Hama, further north. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights which carried the toll said that the 12 civilians were killed in Qusseir during raids for people wanted by the authorities.

refs.text: http://web.archive.org/web/20130610014822/http://www.france24.com/en/20110925-syria-sends-troop-reinforcements-homs-area

21 September.event: Syrian security forces killed at least 76 people in the past five days as part of a crackdown on protests against President Bashar al-Assad’s government, a human rights activist said. At least seven people were killed today in the central governorate of Homs, following the death of 15 protesters yesterday there and in Hama, the northern province of Idlib and in the southern area of Daraa, where the uprising against Assad began in March, Mahmoud Merhi, head of the Arab Organization for Human Rights, said by phone today. State media said “terrorists” killed General Nael al-Dakhil, deputy chief of the chemistry faculty at Al-Baath University in Homs, and Mohammad Ali Akeel, deputy dean of its architecture faculty. Activists said security forces murdered them after they expressed opposition to the crackdown. Homs is a focal point of the uprising against Assad’s government and the hometown of his wife, Asma.

refs.text: Syria Forces Kill 76 in Five Days of Violence, Activist Says

21 September.event: The Free Syrian Army claimed to have destroyed 17 loyalist tanks in the town of Rastan, and there were reports of more defections occurring with the ranks of the Syrian Army, raising fears that civil war could break out.

refs.text: As troops defect, Syria risks civil war

21 September.event: At least 38 loyalist soldiers were injured in Rastan, some critically.
The Harmoush battalion also reported that it killed 80 loyalist soldiers in fighting.

refs.text: Defected brigade says it has killed 80 members of Assad’s forces

21 September.event: About 100 "pro-assad" protesters attempted to attack the U.S. ambassadors convoy, but Ambassador Ford and his convoy remained unharmed in the incident. Security forces killed 17 protesters throughout Syria, and the Opposition prepared for a new Friday of Protests, under the Banner of Friday of Victory for the Levant and Yemen.

refs.text: https://web.archive.org/20110929172319/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/09/29/bloomberg_articlesLSAL2H6JTSE8.DTL

21 September.event: Syrian security forces have clashed with protesters, killing at least 30 people as tens of thousands have rallied across the country calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down, activists say. There were reports that the security forces opened fire on protesters at several of the demonstrations on Friday, and that there were also clashes between troops who have joined the protesters and those loyal to Assad. Protests were reported in suburbs of Damascus, the capital, as well as in the southern province of Deraa, the northwestern province of Idlib, in Hama, Homs and several other cities.
An opposition activist, speaking to Al Jazeera on condition of anonymity, described the scene at one protest in Damascus:

refs.text: 'Dozens killed' in Syria protests

21 September.event: The area where I stay now, a protest went around and it was soon attacked by security forces, and the attack included batons, hitting with batons, some gas bombs and later live ammunition that was shot all around. At least one person was injured. Later, after that, we could see a number of soldiers – we could see a clash between the soldiers and the security forces. And my friends confirmed that eight soldiers at least defected and shot back on the security forces.

22 December.event: Fresh raids and gunfire by government forces on Thursday killed at least 19 people, most of them in the central city of Homs and northern Idlib province, according to the London-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Local Coordination Committees.

refs.text: Despite observers, Syria's Assad hikes crackdown

22 December.event: The Syrian government updated the casualty figures of its soldiers to 2,000, as the Arab League prepared an agreed observer mission into the country, amongst rising civilian, defector, and soldier deaths from ongoing clashes in the Zawiya mountains near Idlib.

refs.text: Arab League delegates head to Syria over 'bloodbath'

22 December.event: Two car bombings in Damascus at security offices killed civilians and some soldiers, leaving 44 dead and 163 wounded. Syrian officials said that Al Qaeda was suspected of carrying out the attack. A website, which supposedly belonged to the Muslim Brotherhood, emerged claiming the attacks. It was later revealed that the website was fake and made by the Syrian regime only one day before the bombings. Also, many members of the organization were interviewed on several channels and denied any relation between them and the Damascus events.

refs.text: Muslim Brotherhood denies Syria bombing claim

22 December.event: Meanwhile, the opposition said the Syrian government may have orchestrated the attacks to reinforce its narrative of a country beset by terrorist-related violence.

refs.text: Funeral for Damascus Bombing Victims Turns into Pro-Assad Rally

22 December.event: The government of Lebanon had reportedly warned Damascus two days prior that Al Qaida infiltrated Syria from Arsal, Lebanon.

refs.text: Lebanon warned Syria warned of al Qaeda infiltration

22 December.event: Daily Friday protests occurred throughout Syria, most notably in Idlib, Homs, Qamishli, Hama, Damascus and its suburbs. As many as 28 people were killed as Syrian security forces continued with its crackdown against protesters and dissents in the country, Al Arabiya reported, citing Syrian activists.

refs.text: Arab League monitors to leave for Syria Monday as more deaths reported in crackdown

22 December.event: Thousands rallied in support of Assad in Damascus at the funeral of the victims of the previous day's bombings, blaming the attacks on the Syrian opposition and Qatar. Arab League Secretary-General Nabil Elaraby condemned the attacks in a statement.

refs.text: Funeral for Damascus Bombing Victims Turns into Pro-Assad Rally

22 December.event: Meanwhile, Oil Minister Sufian Allaw said oil production in Syria had fallen by between 30 percent and 35 percent due to foreign sanctions preventing exports.

refs.text: Allaw: current output was about 260,000 barrels per day

22 December.event: Sudanese General Mohammed Ahmed Mustafa al-Dabi, the leader of a planned Arab League observer mission, arrived in Damascus to meet with the Syrian government ahead of the mission's official start.

refs.text: First Arab monitors arrive in Syria: source

22 December.event: Burhan Ghalioun called for the Arab League and the United Nations Security Council to coordinate efforts to hold the Syrian government accountable for the bloodshed. In the Homsi neighborhood of Baba Amr, at least 15 civilians were killed by artillery bombardment, activists said. As many as 4,000 soldiers were reported to have surrounded the city.

refs.text: Syrian National Council calls for Arab League monitor to go to besieged Homs

22 December.event: Residents said at least 34 were killed in Homs, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said four died in Hama, two died in Idlib, one died in Daraa, and one more died in a suburb of Damascus as a result of security forces' actions, for a total death toll of 42 throughout the country related to the uprising for the day.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

22 December.event: Some Homs residents posted amateur video to the Internet showing what appear to be army tanks moving through the city, firing on apartment buildings with machine guns and mortar rounds, and mangled bodies and pools of blood, as well as ruined cars and power lines, in the streets of the city. At least one resident reported seeing army ambulances carrying wounded soldiers, suggesting that militant elements of the Syrian opposition were fighting back against the military crackdown in Homs. The Observatory also reported clashes and arrests in Aleppo.

refs.text: Syria Violence: Government Tanks Unleash Fire On Protesters, Killing At Least 20

22 December.event: Meanwhile, 50 Arab League monitors headed to Damascus as opposition members sought to downplay the mission, saying Syrian authorities were likely to stymie its chances of uncovering the truth and block observers' access to some of the worst-hit parts of the country, and the French government insisted on greater transparency.

refs.text: Arab monitors head to Syria, opposition skeptical

22 December.event: The observers arrived in the Syrian capital after sundown, sources told Reuters.

refs.text: First Arab monitors arrive in Syria: source

22 December.event: At least 11 tanks that had been shelling the neighbourhood of Baba Amr in Homs, according to residents and opposition activists, reportedly withdrew ahead of Arab League monitors' visit to the city.

refs.text: Arab monitors reach Homs, Syrian tanks seen leaving

22 December.event: More than 2,000 Homsis turned out for a sit-in protest awaiting the Arab League team's arrival, an activist said.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

22 December.event: Al Jazeera reported thousands more marched in protest at the funeral of a city resident killed the previous day.

refs.text: Tue, 27 Dec 2011, 11:16 GMT+3 – Syria

22 December.event: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights put the number of protesters in the Khalidiyah neighbourhood at 20,000, while the Local Co-ordinating Committees said turnout there was closer to 35,000.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

22 December.event: Over 70,000

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

22 December.event: protesters reportedly converged on Clock Square in the center of the city, apparently after hearing Arab League monitors were in the area, but an activist said security forces began firing tear gas and live ammunition and prevented them from occupying the square. Elsewhere in Homs, including in besieged Baba Amr, the Observatory said gunfire, including volleys from snipers, impaired the free movement of residents.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

22 December.event: Although General Dabi, the leader of the observer team, said the day proceeded well and "all sides were very responsive", amateur video footage posted on the Internet appeared to show anti-government Homsis unsuccessfully pleading with monitors to travel further into the Baba Amr neighbourhood, where extensive violence had been reported.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

22 December.event: Avaaz claimed similar scenes of civil protest and regime violence in Hama, where thousands of demonstrators marching to al-Assi Square in the city centre were scattered by troops firing live ammunition, according to activists. Thirty-three deaths were reported in total throughout Syria by the LCC, including 13 in Homs, four in Daraa, four near Damascus, three at Damascus University, three in Hama, three in Idlib, two in Deir ez-Zor, and one in Latakia. The incident at Damascus University occurred when, the Observatory claimed, a student recently detained and tortured by the regime opened fire on fellow students who vocally supported Assad. The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on the school shooting, but made no mention of any political motivation on the shooter's part. SANA also claimed a terrorist attack shut down a natural gas pumping operation in Homs Governorate.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

22 December.event: At least 13 people were killed in fresh violence across Syria, activists said, as Arab League observers continued their mission. Six of the dead were reportedly killed while protesting in Hama. Local rights groups say others were killed in Homs, Aleppo, and Idlib. Video shared by activists from the protest in Hama showed gunshots being fired and black smoke rising above the city. Dozens of men were marching through the streets, chanting "Where are the Arab monitors?" In Deraa, army defectors killed at least four Syrian soldiers in an ambush.

refs.text: Fresh violence hits Syria flashpoint towns

22 December.event: Protesters demanded the removal of Mustafa Dabi as leader of the Arab League monitoring team as observers visited Hama, where six more people were killed, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Al Jazeera reported that an anonymous official with the observing mission in Syria had said monitors had witnessed shelling in Homs and it was apparent some parts of the city were controlled by the Free Syrian Army. The official, whose report directly contradicted Dabi's account of the situation, predicted the mission was doomed to fail. The LCC put the nationwide death toll at 35 for the day,

refs.text: Violence and doubts mar Syria monitor mission

22 December.event: while the Observatory said 26 were confirmed dead, with four deaths allegedly occurring in Douma after security forces fired live ammunition into a crowd of about 20,000 massing at its Grand Mosque for a protest ahead of an expected visit by Arab League observers. The Observatory said Douma residents responded to the shootings in their city by organising a mass strike and flooding into the city square for a sit-in thousands strong. The report could not be immediately confirmed, nor could rumours that Arab League vehicles were sighted in Douma. Hundreds also reportedly protested in Midan, a central Damascus neighbourhood, before being dispersed by soldiers shooting tear gas. The Observatory claimed 150,000 marched in the streets in Idlib Governorate, its largest demonstration in recent days. After meeting with Nabil Elaraby, head of the Arab League, Syrian National Council leader Burhan Ghalioun said he feared the Syrian government held more than 100,000 detainees and could execute them "to say there are no prisoners" if Arab League monitors demanded access to facilities in which they are imprisoned.

refs.text: Arab League monitors stoke anti-government protests in Syria

22 December.event: Activists said more than 130 protesters had been confirmed killed, including six children, since the Arab League observers arrived in Syria earlier in the week.

refs.text: Syrian Troops Filmed 'Targeting Civilians'

22 December.event: During the day, that reported death toll grew to 32 following attacks from security forces. BBC News gave a death toll of 35 for the day.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

22 December.event: In what seemed to be the largest day of demonstrating, with more than 500,000 people demonstrating in two governorates alone: Hama and Idlib, over 6 million people are said to have rallied in Syria against Bashar Al-Assad, according to activists. Tens of thousands protested in Damascus, as well as tens of thousands in Homs. Smaller demonstrations occurred in Daraa, Deir Ezzor, and Aleppo.

refs.text: Clashes erupt as protests spread across Syria
Death toll up as Syria forces fire nail bombs; U.N. wants ‘unhindered’ observer access

22 December.event: Amateur video posted online appeared to show an orange-vested Arab League observer in Daraa responding to residents' claims that snipers were nearby by saying he had seen the snipers himself and telling them the monitors planned to ask the Syrian government to remove any snipers from Daraa within 24 hours.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

22 December.event: In Cairo, the SNC and the National Coordination Body for Democratic Change in Syria signed onto a political roadmap for a transition to democracy in Syria to be put into effect if Assad is deposed.

refs.text: Syrian Opposition Groups Unite to Chart Path to Democracy

22 December.event: Activists reported at least nine deaths, at least three of them in Homs, at least one in Damascus, and at least one in Abu Kamal, as security forces attacked large protests across the country. The LCC said some protests evolved from funeral marches for demonstrators killed the day before.

refs.text: 9 Killed in Syria, Opposition Groups Unite

22 December.event: Al Jazeera reported that the number of statements received by the network from Arab League observers critical of the regime's crackdown had mounted over the past two days. Meanwhile, the SNC signed a deal with the National Co-ordination Committee, to work together on developing a "parliamentary system for a democratic, pluralistic civil state [that] guarantees the exchange of power through elections".

refs.text: Arab mission warns Syria as opposition unites

22 December.event: The head of the Arab League's observing team, General Mustafa Dabi, said in an interview with the BBC News on Newshour that no observers saw snipers in Deraa, contradicting amateur video showing an observer telling activists he saw snipers in the city centre. Dabi claimed that the observer was making "a hypothetical remark only".

refs.text: Arab League mission chief dispute Syria sniper account

22 November.event: Britain, France and Germany asked the United Nations to pass a resolution condemning Syrian violence against opposition protesters.

refs.text: Syria: UN human rights committee condemns crackdown

22 November.event: French foreign minister Alain Juppé assured Syrian opposition forces that NATO powers are considering to launch an intervention by imposing “humanitarian corridors or humanitarian zones” in the name of protecting civilians from the alleged abuses of the Assad regime.

refs.text: Russia Arms Syria With Missiles To Defend Against NATO Attack

22 November.event: The Al-Arabia network reports that 12 people were killed in clashes between Syrian security forces and anti-regime demonstrators.

refs.text: Syria: 12 Dead in Clashes With Security Forces

22 November.event: As Friday protests were held, Russia, China, and their partners in the BRICS group of emerging economies urged Syria to start talks with the opposition and warned against foreign intervention without UN backing.

refs.text: Russia, China, urge Syria talks, stress U.N. role

22 November.event: The deadline for Syria to avoid Arab League sanctions passed.

refs.text: Syria faces Friday deadline to avoid Arab League sanctions

22 November.event: The Syrian military claimed that the Free Syrian Army attacked a military base in the Homs province, killing 10 members of Assad's air force. Of the 10 killed, six were "elite military pilots" in the Homs Province Ambush

refs.text: Syria: Elite Military Pilots Reportedly Killed In Ambush

22 November.event: The Free Syrian Army ambushed the Syrian army in Idlib, killing eight loyalist soldiers. The Free Syrian Army had no casualties.

refs.text: Arab League draws up sanctions on Syria, as fresh violence kills scores

22 November.event: The Arab League agreed on economic sanctions against Syria, including a freeze on doing business with the Central Bank of Syria and the Syrian government, a travel ban on regime officials, and a suspension of infrastructure spending by Arab governments in Syria.

refs.text: Arab League approves Syria sanctions

22 November.event: Three civilians were injured and one other killed in a raid by security forces in the town of Saraqeb. The Free Syrian Army also killed three loyalist soldiers and captured two others.

Al Jazeera reported that an anonymous official with the observing mission in Syria had said monitors had witnessed shelling in Homs and it was apparent some parts of the city were controlled by the Free Syrian Army. The official, whose report directly contradicted Dabi's account of the situation, predicted the mission was doomed to fail. The LCC put the nationwide death toll at 35 for the day,

refs.text: Violence and doubts mar Syria monitor mission

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: while the Observatory said 26 were confirmed dead, with four deaths allegedly occurring in Douma after security forces fired live ammunition into a crowd of about 20,000 massing at its Grand Mosque for a protest ahead of an expected visit by Arab League observers. The Observatory said Douma residents responded to the shootings in their city by organising a mass strike and flooding into the city square for a sit-in thousands strong. The report could not be immediately confirmed, nor could rumours that Arab League vehicles were sighted in Douma. Hundreds also reportedly protested in Midan, a central Damascus neighbourhood, before being dispersed by soldiers shooting tear gas. The Observatory claimed 150,000 marched in the streets in Idlib Governorate, its largest demonstration in recent days. After meeting with Nabil Elaraby, head of the Arab League, Syrian National Council leader Burhan Ghalioun said he feared the Syrian government held more than 100,000 detainees and could execute them "to say there are no prisoners" if Arab League monitors demanded access to facilities in which they are imprisoned.

refs.text: Arab League monitors stoke anti-government protests in Syria

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: Activists said more than 130 protesters had been confirmed killed, including six children, since the Arab League observers arrived in Syria earlier in the week.

refs.text: Syrian Troops Filmed 'Targeting Civilians'

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: During the day, that reported death toll grew to 32 following attacks from security forces. BBC News gave a death toll of 35 for the day.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: In what seemed to be the largest day of demonstrating, with more than 500,000 people demonstrating in two governorates alone: Hama and Idlib, over 6 million people are said to have rallied in Syria against Bashar Al-Assad, according to activists. Tens of thousands protested in Damascus, as well as tens of thousands in Homs. Smaller demonstrations occurred in Daraa, Deir Ezzor, and Aleppo.

refs.text: Clashes erupt as protests spread across Syria
Death toll up as Syria forces fire nail bombs; U.N. wants ‘unhindered’ observer access

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: Amateur video posted online appeared to show an orange-vested Arab League observer in Daraa responding to residents' claims that snipers were nearby by saying he had seen the snipers himself and telling them the monitors planned to ask the Syrian government to remove any snipers from Daraa within 24 hours.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: In Cairo, the SNC and the National Coordination Body for Democratic Change in Syria signed onto a political roadmap for a transition to democracy in Syria to be put into effect if Assad is deposed.

refs.text: Syrian Opposition Groups Unite to Chart Path to Democracy

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: Activists reported at least nine deaths, at least three of them in Homs, at least one in Damascus, and at least one in Abu Kamal, as security forces attacked large protests across the country. The LCC said some protests evolved from funeral marches for demonstrators killed the day before.

refs.text: 9 Killed in Syria, Opposition Groups Unite

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: Al Jazeera reported that the number of statements received by the network from Arab League observers critical of the regime's crackdown had mounted over the past two days. Meanwhile, the SNC signed a deal with the National Co-ordination Committee, to work together on developing a "parliamentary system for a democratic, pluralistic civil state [that] guarantees the exchange of power through elections".

refs.text: Arab mission warns Syria as opposition unites

23 December \u2013 \"Friday of the Proto.event: The head of the Arab League's observing team, General Mustafa Dabi, said in an interview with the BBC News on Newshour that no observers saw snipers in Deraa, contradicting amateur video showing an observer telling activists he saw snipers in the city centre. Dabi claimed that the observer was making "a hypothetical remark only".

23 November.event: French foreign minister Alain Juppé assured Syrian opposition forces that NATO powers are considering to launch an intervention by imposing “humanitarian corridors or humanitarian zones” in the name of protecting civilians from the alleged abuses of the Assad regime.

refs.text: Russia Arms Syria With Missiles To Defend Against NATO Attack

23 November.event: The Al-Arabia network reports that 12 people were killed in clashes between Syrian security forces and anti-regime demonstrators.

refs.text: Syria: 12 Dead in Clashes With Security Forces

23 November.event: As Friday protests were held, Russia, China, and their partners in the BRICS group of emerging economies urged Syria to start talks with the opposition and warned against foreign intervention without UN backing.

refs.text: Russia, China, urge Syria talks, stress U.N. role

23 November.event: The deadline for Syria to avoid Arab League sanctions passed.

refs.text: Syria faces Friday deadline to avoid Arab League sanctions

23 November.event: The Syrian military claimed that the Free Syrian Army attacked a military base in the Homs province, killing 10 members of Assad's air force. Of the 10 killed, six were "elite military pilots" in the Homs Province Ambush

refs.text: Syria: Elite Military Pilots Reportedly Killed In Ambush

23 November.event: The Free Syrian Army ambushed the Syrian army in Idlib, killing eight loyalist soldiers. The Free Syrian Army had no casualties.

refs.text: Arab League draws up sanctions on Syria, as fresh violence kills scores

23 November.event: The Arab League agreed on economic sanctions against Syria, including a freeze on doing business with the Central Bank of Syria and the Syrian government, a travel ban on regime officials, and a suspension of infrastructure spending by Arab governments in Syria.

refs.text: Arab League approves Syria sanctions

23 November.event: Three civilians were injured and one other killed in a raid by security forces in the town of Saraqeb. The Free Syrian Army also killed three loyalist soldiers and captured two others.

refs.text: Syrian rebel ambush said to kill 3 soldiers

23 October.event: Syria's military clampdown on protest hubs, and skirmishes pitting soldiers against gunmen, believed to be defectors, killed at least 11 people on Saturday, activists said. Meanwhile, Iran, Syria's key ally, took a tougher stance against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, openly condemning its crackdown on dissent that has left more than 3,000 people dead, most of them civilians, according to the United Nations. Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad condemned the "killings and massacre" in Syria in an interview with CNN, in the Islamic republic's strongest criticism of its neighbor's deadly repression of protests calling for greater freedom and the fall of the Assad regime.

23 October.event: Clashes occurred in the northwestern town of Maarat al-Numaan on 25 October between loyalists and defected soldiers at a roadblock on the edge of the town. The defectors launched an assault on the government-held roadblock in retaliation against a raid on their positions the previous night.

refs.text: Assad forces fight deserters at northwestern town

23 October.event: At least seven Syrian security agents, including an officer, and possibly as many as 10 were killed in the ambush, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

refs.text: Syrian army deserters kill 10 troops, Assad to meet Arab League committee Wednesday

23 October.event: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said 19 people were killed in Syria, including seven civilians shot by security forces in the Homs Governorate as well as nine loyalist soldiers killed in a rocket attack attributed to defectors. An Arab League delegation led by Secretary-General Nabil al-Arabi arrived in Damascus for talks.

23 October.event: 36 people were reported killed in Syria, most of them in Hama, whilst thousands of protesters marched demanding a no-fly zone be implemented, such as the one in Libya. Over 100 people were wounded and 500 arrested. Despite the threat of violence, around 170 protests took place on Friday, the traditional day of protest.

refs.text: 36 killed in Syria as activists call for 'no-fly' zone

23 October.event: Tanks and artillery blasted the Homs neighbourhood of Bab Amr, the site of a 90-man defection from the Syrian security forces two days before, causing several casualties.

refs.text: Syrian Forces Strike Homs for Second Day

23 October.event: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claimed that 20 soldiers died and 53 were injured in clashes between loyalist troops and "presumed deserters" in Bab Amr as well.

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: Protesters took to the street, with protests occurring in Hama, Homs, Damascus, Aleppo, and Daraa. 50,000 attended an anti-government march in Homs. 12 protesters across Syria were killed by security forces. Amnesty international announced the death and mutilation of an 18-year-old girl in the hands of the Syrian army. The girl's body was returned to her mother by the Syrian army, and the corpse had clear signs of torture, including skin ripped off and her arms cut off.

refs.text: More deaths in Syria as sanctions tighten

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: Turkey continued to attempt to alienate the Syrian government, and has announced that it will be enforcing an arms embargo on Syria, and confiscate any weapon deliveries to Syria by ship. The European Union also toughened sanctions against the Syrian government, while Switzerland established a ban on Syrian oil imports on Friday.

refs.text: Turkey seizes Syrian ship with weapons – PM Erdogan

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: Syria pressed on with a crackdown on anti-regiment dissent Sunday, dispatching troop reinforcements to the flashpoint province of Homs and security forces near Damascus, activists said. "Military reinforcements were sent to Rastan, deploying around the building housing military security, and others to Qusseir," a town on the border with Lebanon, they said. The Syrian army had strengthened its presence in Qusseir on Saturday and previous days after many civilians tried to flee the area to escape the violence. The deployments come a day after activists reported that security forces had killed 12 civilians in Qusseir, in the central province of Homs, and one more in Hama, further north. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights which carried the toll said that the 12 civilians were killed in Qusseir during raids for people wanted by the authorities.

refs.text: http://web.archive.org/web/20130610014822/http://www.france24.com/en/20110925-syria-sends-troop-reinforcements-homs-area

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: Syrian security forces killed at least 76 people in the past five days as part of a crackdown on protests against President Bashar al-Assad’s government, a human rights activist said. At least seven people were killed today in the central governorate of Homs, following the death of 15 protesters yesterday there and in Hama, the northern province of Idlib and in the southern area of Daraa, where the uprising against Assad began in March, Mahmoud Merhi, head of the Arab Organization for Human Rights, said by phone today. State media said “terrorists” killed General Nael al-Dakhil, deputy chief of the chemistry faculty at Al-Baath University in Homs, and Mohammad Ali Akeel, deputy dean of its architecture faculty. Activists said security forces murdered them after they expressed opposition to the crackdown. Homs is a focal point of the uprising against Assad’s government and the hometown of his wife, Asma.

refs.text: Syria Forces Kill 76 in Five Days of Violence, Activist Says

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: The Free Syrian Army claimed to have destroyed 17 loyalist tanks in the town of Rastan, and there were reports of more defections occurring with the ranks of the Syrian Army, raising fears that civil war could break out.

refs.text: As troops defect, Syria risks civil war

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: At least 38 loyalist soldiers were injured in Rastan, some critically.
The Harmoush battalion also reported that it killed 80 loyalist soldiers in fighting.

refs.text: Defected brigade says it has killed 80 members of Assad’s forces

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: About 100 "pro-assad" protesters attempted to attack the U.S. ambassadors convoy, but Ambassador Ford and his convoy remained unharmed in the incident. Security forces killed 17 protesters throughout Syria, and the Opposition prepared for a new Friday of Protests, under the Banner of Friday of Victory for the Levant and Yemen.

refs.text: https://web.archive.org/20110929172319/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/09/29/bloomberg_articlesLSAL2H6JTSE8.DTL

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: Syrian security forces have clashed with protesters, killing at least 30 people as tens of thousands have rallied across the country calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down, activists say. There were reports that the security forces opened fire on protesters at several of the demonstrations on Friday, and that there were also clashes between troops who have joined the protesters and those loyal to Assad. Protests were reported in suburbs of Damascus, the capital, as well as in the southern province of Deraa, the northwestern province of Idlib, in Hama, Homs and several other cities.
An opposition activist, speaking to Al Jazeera on condition of anonymity, described the scene at one protest in Damascus:

refs.text: 'Dozens killed' in Syria protests

23 September \u2013 \"Friday of Unificat.event: The area where I stay now, a protest went around and it was soon attacked by security forces, and the attack included batons, hitting with batons, some gas bombs and later live ammunition that was shot all around. At least one person was injured. Later, after that, we could see a number of soldiers – we could see a clash between the soldiers and the security forces. And my friends confirmed that eight soldiers at least defected and shot back on the security forces.

24 December.event: Thousands rallied in support of Assad in Damascus at the funeral of the victims of the previous day's bombings, blaming the attacks on the Syrian opposition and Qatar. Arab League Secretary-General Nabil Elaraby condemned the attacks in a statement.

24 December.event: Meanwhile, Oil Minister Sufian Allaw said oil production in Syria had fallen by between 30 percent and 35 percent due to foreign sanctions preventing exports.

24 December.event: Burhan Ghalioun called for the Arab League and the United Nations Security Council to coordinate efforts to hold the Syrian government accountable for the bloodshed. In the Homsi neighborhood of Baba Amr, at least 15 civilians were killed by artillery bombardment, activists said. As many as 4,000 soldiers were reported to have surrounded the city.

24 December.event: Residents said at least 34 were killed in Homs, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said four died in Hama, two died in Idlib, one died in Daraa, and one more died in a suburb of Damascus as a result of security forces' actions, for a total death toll of 42 throughout the country related to the uprising for the day.

24 December.event: Some Homs residents posted amateur video to the Internet showing what appear to be army tanks moving through the city, firing on apartment buildings with machine guns and mortar rounds, and mangled bodies and pools of blood, as well as ruined cars and power lines, in the streets of the city. At least one resident reported seeing army ambulances carrying wounded soldiers, suggesting that militant elements of the Syrian opposition were fighting back against the military crackdown in Homs. The Observatory also reported clashes and arrests in Aleppo.

24 December.event: Although General Dabi, the leader of the observer team, said the day proceeded well and "all sides were very responsive", amateur video footage posted on the Internet appeared to show anti-government Homsis unsuccessfully pleading with monitors to travel further into the Baba Amr neighbourhood, where extensive violence had been reported.

24 December.event: Avaaz claimed similar scenes of civil protest and regime violence in Hama, where thousands of demonstrators marching to al-Assi Square in the city centre were scattered by troops firing live ammunition, according to activists. Thirty-three deaths were reported in total throughout Syria by the LCC, including 13 in Homs, four in Daraa, four near Damascus, three at Damascus University, three in Hama, three in Idlib, two in Deir ez-Zor, and one in Latakia. The incident at Damascus University occurred when, the Observatory claimed, a student recently detained and tortured by the regime opened fire on fellow students who vocally supported Assad. The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on the school shooting, but made no mention of any political motivation on the shooter's part. SANA also claimed a terrorist attack shut down a natural gas pumping operation in Homs Governorate.

refs.text: Security forces fire on protesters in Homs, Hama

24 December.event: At least 13 people were killed in fresh violence across Syria, activists said, as Arab League observers continued their mission. Six of the dead were reportedly killed while protesting in Hama. Local rights groups say others were killed in Homs, Aleppo, and Idlib. Video shared by activists from the protest in Hama showed gunshots being fired and black smoke rising above the city. Dozens of men were marching through the streets, chanting "Where are the Arab monitors?" In Deraa, army defectors killed at least four Syrian soldiers in an ambush.

The Observatory claimed 150,000 marched in the streets in Idlib Governorate, its largest demonstration in recent days. After meeting with Nabil Elaraby, head of the Arab League, Syrian National Council leader Burhan Ghalioun said he feared the Syrian government held more than 100,000 detainees and could execute them "to say there are no prisoners" if Arab League monitors demanded access to facilities in which they are imprisoned.

refs.text: Arab League monitors stoke anti-government protests in Syria

refs.text: Syrian Troops Filmed 'Targeting Civilians'

25 December.event: During the day, that reported death toll grew to 32 following attacks from security forces. BBC News gave a death toll of 35 for the day.

refs.text: Arab League observer 'concern' at Syria snipers

25 December.event: In what seemed to be the largest day of demonstrating, with more than 500,000 people demonstrating in two governorates alone: Hama and Idlib, over 6 million people are said to have rallied in Syria against Bashar Al-Assad, according to activists. Tens of thousands protested in Damascus, as well as tens of thousands in Homs. Smaller demonstrations occurred in Daraa, Deir Ezzor, and Aleppo.

refs.text: 9 Killed in Syria, Opposition Groups Unite

Meanwhile, the SNC signed a deal with the National Co-ordination Committee, to work together on developing a "parliamentary system for a democratic, pluralistic civil state [that] guarantees the exchange of power through elections".

Dabi claimed that the observer was making "a hypothetical remark only".

25 September.event: Syria pressed on with a crackdown on anti-regiment dissent Sunday, dispatching troop reinforcements to the flashpoint province of Homs and security forces near Damascus, activists said. "Military reinforcements were sent to Rastan, deploying around the building housing military security, and others to Qusseir," a town on the border with Lebanon, they said. The Syrian army had strengthened its presence in Qusseir on Saturday and previous days after many civilians tried to flee the area to escape the violence. The deployments come a day after activists reported that security forces had killed 12 civilians in Qusseir, in the central province of Homs, and one more in Hama, further north. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights which carried the toll said that the 12 civilians were killed in Qusseir during raids for people wanted by the authorities.

refs.text: http://web.archive.org/web/20130610014822/http://www.france24.com/en/20110925-syria-sends-troop-reinforcements-homs-area

25 September.event: Syrian security forces killed at least 76 people in the past five days as part of a crackdown on protests against President Bashar al-Assad’s government, a human rights activist said. At least seven people were killed today in the central governorate of Homs, following the death of 15 protesters yesterday there and in Hama, the northern province of Idlib and in the southern area of Daraa, where the uprising against Assad began in March, Mahmoud Merhi, head of the Arab Organization for Human Rights, said by phone today. State media said “terrorists” killed General Nael al-Dakhil, deputy chief of the chemistry faculty at Al-Baath University in Homs, and Mohammad Ali Akeel, deputy dean of its architecture faculty. Activists said security forces murdered them after they expressed opposition to the crackdown. Homs is a focal point of the uprising against Assad’s government and the hometown of his wife, Asma.

refs.text: Syria Forces Kill 76 in Five Days of Violence, Activist Says

25 September.event: The Free Syrian Army claimed to have destroyed 17 loyalist tanks in the town of Rastan, and there were reports of more defections occurring with the ranks of the Syrian Army, raising fears that civil war could break out.

refs.text: As troops defect, Syria risks civil war

25 September.event: At least 38 loyalist soldiers were injured in Rastan, some critically.
The Harmoush battalion also reported that it killed 80 loyalist soldiers in fighting.

refs.text: Defected brigade says it has killed 80 members of Assad’s forces

25 September.event: About 100 "pro-assad" protesters attempted to attack the U.S. ambassadors convoy, but Ambassador Ford and his convoy remained unharmed in the incident. Security forces killed 17 protesters throughout Syria, and the Opposition prepared for a new Friday of Protests, under the Banner of Friday of Victory for the Levant and Yemen.

refs.text: https://web.archive.org/20110929172319/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/09/29/bloomberg_articlesLSAL2H6JTSE8.DTL

25 September.event: Syrian security forces have clashed with protesters, killing at least 30 people as tens of thousands have rallied across the country calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down, activists say. There were reports that the security forces opened fire on protesters at several of the demonstrations on Friday, and that there were also clashes between troops who have joined the protesters and those loyal to Assad. Protests were reported in suburbs of Damascus, the capital, as well as in the southern province of Deraa, the northwestern province of Idlib, in Hama, Homs and several other cities.
An opposition activist, speaking to Al Jazeera on condition of anonymity, described the scene at one protest in Damascus:

refs.text: 'Dozens killed' in Syria protests

25 September.event: The area where I stay now, a protest went around and it was soon attacked by security forces, and the attack included batons, hitting with batons, some gas bombs and later live ammunition that was shot all around. At least one person was injured. Later, after that, we could see a number of soldiers – we could see a clash between the soldiers and the security forces. And my friends confirmed that eight soldiers at least defected and shot back on the security forces.

26 December.event: Residents said at least 34 were killed in Homs, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights in London said four died in Hama, two died in Idlib, one died in Daraa, and one more died in a suburb of Damascus as a result of security forces' actions, for a total death toll of 42 throughout the country related to the uprising for the day.

refs.text: 70,000 demonstrators gather in Syrian city of Homs as Arab League observers arrive after third consecutive day of bloodshed

26 December.event: Some Homs residents posted amateur video to the Internet showing what appear to be army tanks moving through the city, firing on apartment buildings with machine guns and mortar rounds, and mangled bodies and pools of blood, as well as ruined cars and power lines, in the streets of the city. At least one resident reported seeing army ambulances carrying wounded soldiers, suggesting that militant elements of the Syrian opposition were fighting back against the military crackdown in Homs. The Observatory also reported clashes and arrests in Aleppo.

refs.text: Syria Violence: Government Tanks Unleash Fire On Protesters, Killing At Least 20

26 December.event: Avaaz claimed similar scenes of civil protest and regime violence in Hama, where thousands of demonstrators marching to al-Assi Square in the city centre were scattered by troops firing live ammunition, according to activists. Thirty-three deaths were reported in total throughout Syria by the LCC, including 13 in Homs, four in Daraa, four near Damascus, three at Damascus University, three in Hama, three in Idlib, two in Deir ez-Zor, and one in Latakia. The incident at Damascus University occurred when, the Observatory claimed, a student recently detained and tortured by the regime opened fire on fellow students who vocally supported Assad. The Syrian Arab News Agency reported on the school shooting, but made no mention of any political motivation on the shooter's part. SANA also claimed a terrorist attack shut down a natural gas pumping operation in Homs Governorate.

Six of the dead were reportedly killed while protesting in Hama. Local rights groups say others were killed in Homs, Aleppo, and Idlib. Video shared by activists from the protest in Hama showed gunshots being fired and black smoke rising above the city. Dozens of men were marching through the streets, chanting "Where are the Arab monitors?" In Deraa, army defectors killed at least four Syrian soldiers in an ambush.
